title: PHPetite – A Single File Blog
Ask HN: Has a corporate engineering blog made you want to join the company?
text:
Dan Luu wrote this fascinating post a while back (https://danluu.com/corp-eng-blogs/), proposing, "Companies compete relatively directly when recruiting, so being more compelling relative to another company has value to them; replicating the playbook Cloudflare or Segment has used with their engineering 'brands' would be a significant recruiting advantage."

Have you applied to work at a company after reading its engineering blog?

Ask HN: Are you using .NET to write cross-platform desktop or mobile apps?
text:
Microsoft's .NET is an open-source platform for building desktop apps and mobile apps (and more) using C#, F# and Visual Basic. Does this sound too good to be true?

For example, Electron is often discussed on HN (liked and disliked), but .NET is far less discussed as a cross-platform option.

Similarly, Xamarin is a platform built on top of .NET for building Android and iOS apps (using one codebase). This sounds like the holy grail of mobile development. But what is the reality?

I did a search on HN and found no stories about Xamarin from the last year. The top search results are HN stories from 5-10 years ago. This makes me wonder how popular .NET is for cross-platform desktop or mobile apps.

What has been your experience using .NET writing cross-platform desktop and mobile apps?

title: Ask HN: What would your ideal professional social network look like?
text:
Now that LinkedIn is slowly turning into Facebook complete with pictures of crying CEOs and humblebrag stories about children, I feel that there is room for a new platform with limited posting abilities and a greater focus on one’s skills and accomplishments.

What would you like to see on a professional social network platform? And maybe more importantly, what do you not want to see?
